Text: Eventually the glare withdraws to reveal a lone woman.
She has long, black tresses and eyes of vivid violet.

Her sable robe is thin, allowing the deep purple
dress she wears beneath it and her pale skin to
show through.

There is an artistic beauty to her, like a sculpture
brought to life.
It cannot be...
Not her...
Aurora the Calamity Witch.
Whaaat?
...Natsume. Who is this "Aurora"?
Aurora the Calamity Witch.

A woman who wrought chaos and destruction upon the
world in ages past.
This is the first I've heard of her...
...I'm surprised you know all that.
All part of being an author.
Still, while Aurora is thought to be the Calamity Witch,

no records remain of exactly what kind of chaos and
destruction she actually caused.
Beta isn't lying.

Aurora the Calamity Witch. Any delve into ancient
history will invariably mention her name.

The Shadow Garden has been investigating her as the
next most important mystery from the distant past to
solve after Diablos.

And here today, they finally got a first real look at
her. This is a huge step.
Beta pulls a notepad out of her cleavage.
Oh my...!
Archbishop?
If you don't mind,
could you tell me about the Calamity Witch?
Wh-Why yes, of course.

Nelson puffs himself up importantly and complies
with Beta's fawning request.

Yes, well. It's not surprising young ladies of gentle
birth such as yourselves would not know all this.

I must admit I am surprised that Lady Kafka has some
familiarity with the topic, however.

At any rate, the name Aurora is known to only a
select few even within the Church.
This does bode ill for that Shadow, I'm afraid.
I never suspected Aurora might appear.

She is referred to as the most powerful witch in
history. A hooligan like him stands no chance
against her.

Nelson stops there, all but saying, "You'll see
what I mean in a second."

Beta gives an irritated huff, not thinking for even a
fraction of a second that her lord could ever lose.
This doesn't mean she is entirely free of worry,
though.

Aurora the Calamity Witch. Her might was such that
it carved her name into the annals of time.

If her lord tires during his battle with the witch,
the unthinkable might happen if the paladins
seize upon the moment to strike.

Having come this far, Beta can faintly guess at her
lord's intentions.

Shadow had said that he'd release ancient memories
slumbering in the Sanctuary.

He had acted so that Aurora would be called forth.
There must be some merit in doing so.
Her lord had judged that Aurora was the key.
In which case, it falls on Beta to follow his lead.

Beta puts a hand to the beauty mark beneath her eye.
It is a signal indicating a change in plans.

It likely reached Epsilon, who is hiding in the venue.
Beta trusts that she will adopt the best course of
action without any detailed instructions.

She looks toward the arena and sees Shadow, who has
drawn his ebony blade, and Aurora, smiling gracefully
with her arms crossed.

It is a smile so beautiful and full of life that one
could hardly think she exists as only a memory.
...I see.

So if the Goddess' Trial summoned that Aurora woman
as a suitable opponent for Shadow,

that means his strength approaches that of someone
who once destroyed the world.
I suspect he won't lose so easily.

Alexia's tone is quiet and her face intent as she
stares at Shadow.
Beta must admit that Alexia has a good eye.
The atmosphere in the arena grows tense.
A heavy silence takes hold.

I look the woman in her violet eyes and grin behind
my mask.
She smiles back.
(We're on the same wavelength.)
(Battle is a conversation.)
(The tremor of a sword's tip...)
(A shift in gaze...)
(The position of one's feet...)
(The opponent's intent is in each of these.)

The stronger the conversational skills of each side,
the greater their ability to guess the other's next
move, respond appropriately, and then see even
further and make counters for that.
Back and forth in an endless exchange.

But if their conversational skills are weak or the
difference in ability is too lopsided, you won't be
able to get a dialogue started to begin with.

All you'll get is one or both sides doing whatever the
hell they want.

There's no conversation or even a process thereonly
results.

And if you never intended to have a conversation, you
may as well settle things rock-paper-scissors style.

(I'm talking about you, Delta. You and your crazy
style of forever choosing rock and smashing the
crap out of paper and scissors.)

(But I shouldn't be criticizing others, especially
when I haven't had anything resembling a real
conversation in forever.)

Unlike Delta, I at least try to communicate going in.
I just always end up picking rock and clobbering the
other guy.)

(That's why I'm happier than I've been in a while
to meet this lady. She's watching me.)

(I think I'll call her Violet. My dear, beloved
Violet.)

For a while, the two of us converse by merely staring
at each other.
As we do so, we learn bit by bit.
(She's the type who fights from a distance...)

(while I'm fundamentally the type who adapts to the
style of whoever I'm up against. I'm definitely not
the type to brute force my way to victory.)
And so...
After you, I imply.
I cede the initiative.
The next instant, I yank back my front leg.

As I do, something like a red spear shoots up where
my foot was.

I take another half step back. It didn't occur to me
that she'd strike from underground.
What the...?!

The spear splits into two, coming at me from both
sides.
My first step is to observe.

I assess the speed of these spears, their power,
their mobility.
Any spear I dodge divides yet again.

I guess there are probably a thousand of these red,
wire-thin needles now.
They turn on me at once from every direction.

I pump magic into my blade and unleash it in a
single sweep
wiping out all the spears in one go.
Not even a swarm of mosquitoes can fell a lion.
Violet beams with grace.

We go back to staring at each other again for a
moment.
